Iterators

Iterators are objects similar to pointers in the way that they point to other objects; however the main difference between iterators and pointers is that iterators is its own class and can be bi-directional if you implement your iterator class to do so.


In our course, we will mainly use iterators to allow the implementation of ranged-for loops for our classes. For this, our iterator class should include 3 parts: an equality operator, dereference operator, and the ++ operator. The iterator should also store a data pointer to the current object.
